sp.p: No, no—there is my hand.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Eh!—what! good God!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Let me look at you—good God!—don't be alarmed.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: But I am very much alarmed. Am I ill?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I dare say you feel— flurried.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Exceedingly.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Palpitation at the heart'—'tis parchment?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Oh yes—very sudden this. I felt quite well just now.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Did you? That's an alarming symptom; for I have always observed, that nothing makes the physcian look so grave, as the patient's saying he feels quite well. My dear friend, send for one directly.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I don't know what to say, They sometimes save your life; but then it is sure to cost you a guinea.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: And saving yours is certainly not worth it. But I see you are a philosopher—You are prepared for death,

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Oh dear! not at all—I am quite terrified. If perspiration is good for me, I feel that copiously.—What shall I do?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Come, for old acquaintance sake, my grandson shall attend you gratis.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Oh, thank you.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Wonderful physician! Never lost a patient—! (aside.) because he never had a patient to lose. I expect him here in five minutes. You had better go to your room.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Keep yourself warm.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Above all things, don't change your clothes.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I won't.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Shall I button your coat?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: No, no—I'll do that myself.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Go, I'll follow, and talk to you of your latter end, and keep up your spirits.
I believe I am dying. 'Tis very good of you to get me a doctor gratis, (exit, and re-enters.) But I say—who is to pay the apothecary?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I'll settle that too.—(Exit Nicholas.)—Now for Undermine—If he have one spark of humanity in his composition, I'll call it forth; if not, and I can get that coat—

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Nicholas! What April here—I guess your errand, and am sorry, sir, I cannot continue you as steward.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I your steward! No, that is not my errand, I am a feeble fellow, sliding out of the world; but Greville is a noble fellow rising into it. 'Tis respecting him I come. You must assist him. How is he to live?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Oh! his integrity will support him.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p:
True; but consider what a way you
would be in, if you had nothing but your integrity to support you.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Sir, I see you only want to triflle with me.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: True; I only want a trifle of you.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I am flint.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Well; but even flint, when properly hit, will send forth warm, vivid sparks.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I must leave you. Time presses.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: So do his wants.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: A nobleman is waiting for me.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: A bailiff is waiting for him.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: If you proceed, expect some personal insult.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Throw your purse at me. Come—

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I shall burst with rage.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: They will famish with hunger.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Unhand me, I say.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: What, a blow!

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Yes; take him that.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: No, no, that you meant for myself, and I'll take it, so you will give something better to poor Greville.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: You scoundrel! And do you suppose, that because I would submit to a blow to endeavour to save a friend from ruin, that I want the spirit of a man to resent an indignity. Ask my pardon.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Pardon!

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I do—help! help!

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: On your knees, or your last hour is come.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Well, I do—I do, Help! help!

div3.stage: Enter Two Servants.—April throws Undermine from him, who retreats behind the Servants.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Leave my house, sir, leave my house. By heaven, I'll be revenged.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: By hell, you are a villain.

div3.head: SCENE I.—Outside of UNDERMINE'S house.
div3.stage: Enter ROSTRUM and EGERTON with caution.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: That is the house.

sp.speaker: Eger.
sp.p: Does that contain—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Softly—recollect, sir, you are only a subaltern in this affair, and that I am your commanding officer; so, obey orders.

sp.speaker: Eger.
sp.p: How do you intend to proceed?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I am too great a general to communicate my plan of operations; I shall do my duty in giving you possession of the lovely citadel, and then take care and do your duty. (going.) I say, when the alarm is given, do you retreat—you know how to do that, I dare say.

sp.speaker: Eger.
sp.p: I fear to trust my happiness. Can it be possible that my adored girl still thinks with kindness on her poor Egerton? Ah! a noise—what an anxious moment!

div3.stage: Enter Rostrum from the house, with Miss SYDNEY in one band, and repelling UNDERMINE with the other.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I will carry her off.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: You shall not, sir, I am her guardian.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Do you think I care for guardians? dare to stir hand or foot, and I'll crush you into atoms, you old scoundrel. (during this, Egerton discovers himself to Miss Sydney, who runs into his arms.)

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: That will do—zounds! be quiet—they are gone, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Eh! so they are, ha, ha!—well, how did I do it?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Oh, capitally— (rubbing his arm.) has the soldier got her?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: That's as it should be.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Are you mad?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: The matter! why don't you go?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Why zounds! how can you marry the girl if you stand here.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I marry! oh, very true. I declare it quite escaped me.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! run.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I am a-going, a-going, a-going— (returning.) Sir! where shall I bring the bride?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: To Greville's. Go along.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I say—this is management.

sp.speaker: Und
sp.p: Yes, yes—but go along.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Sir, you would make a capital puff at an auction.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Zounds! go. (exit Rostrum.) So that's settled—and now to Greville's in triumph. I'll walk in with erected crest, and—ugh! confound the fellow, how he has bruised me!

div3.head: SCENE II.—An Apartment at Mr. UNDERMINE'S.
div3.stage: NICHOLAS discovered on a couch. APRIL sitting by him with a book.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I wish the doctor were come.—Bless me, I hope I shan't die—I don't care what pain I suffer, so I don't die. Oh! for a swinging rheumatism that would last me twenty years—do read a little to me.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: "Crumbs of comfort for an aged sinner."

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: These books are quite new to me.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Have you had my letter?

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Don't forget—'tis the coat I want—and remember you are a physician, not a farrier.

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: I will—and if I succeed, remember you tip. How do you do?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: That's what I want to know of you.

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: True—oh I see—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Shall I detail my symptoms?

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: No—'tis a clear case—if you were to talk for an hour, I should not know more of your complaint than I do at present.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Bleed him—

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: I will. You have no objection to part with a little blood?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I have an objection to part with any thing.

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p:
Except to advantage. Now, if by sinking an ounce or two of blood, you can produce an
income of sixteen pounds of flesh, the advantage is immense.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: How sensibly he talks! why, 'tis five thousand per cent profit. I'll be bled directly.

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: Help him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: No, no, I can do that myself. (places the coat carefully under the cushion of the sopha.—As he sits down, April slips the coat from under the cushion, winks to Plethora, and exit on tiploe.) 'Tis very terrifying—I'll read a little more. But, doctor, are you sure now I shall not be suddenly called to heaven.

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: I am very sure of that.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Oh, you are. (throwing away the book.) Then, pray, sir, what is my complaint?

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: Complaint! what shall I say? I wish he would return—oh, 'tis the—the glanders.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: The glanders! zounds! do you make a horse of me?

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: No—we will be content with making an ass of you. (aside.)—(Enter April with the coat and will, which he exhibits to Plethora in triumph.) Or perhaps the disorder may be seated in the coats belonging to the stomach.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: No, no—the disorder was seated in the coat belonging to the back, ha, ha! but now 'tis removed, (throwing him his coat.) Do you see this?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: And how the devil could you expect a moment's ease with such a thing as this laying next your heart—you may go—you are quite cured.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Cured! I am ruined. Oh! if I had but touched the thousand pounds, I would not mind the interest—perhaps 'tis not too late.

sp.speaker: April
sp.p: Sole heir without reservation or restriction; huzza!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Sir, honourable sir, will you allow me to ask you one small favour?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Only to delay mentioning this (sighing.) joyful discovery for a few moments. My master and I have a little account to settle, and I should like just to strike a balance before he knows what has happened.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Oh, I understand—we have bled you, and now you want to go and bleed him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Just a little, sir.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: With all my heart, old Nick. Devil claw devil.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Oh, thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: But dispatch—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I fly, sir.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Now with heels as light as our hearts we'll away to Greville's.

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: Stop—stop for me, grandfather.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, old one. Here take my arm—let your grandfather assist you. Upon my soul, I quite forget you.

div3.head: SCENE III.—An elegant Drawing room in GREVILLE'S house, illuminated.—A band of music playing.—A number of Servants dressed in splendid liveries.
div3.stage: Enter UNDERMINE in great elation, joining the music in, "See the conquering hero," &c.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Approach! is Greville gone?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Not yet, sir.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Any of my guests arrived?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Has the Traiteur furnished a splendid entertainment?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Let music usher in the guests.

div3.stage: Enter APRIL singing—"See the conquering hero," &. flourishing the will in his hand; seeing Undermine, he conceals it.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Zounds! he here.— (to the Servant.)— Don't go away, sir.

div3.stage: (places the Servant between him and April.)

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: How do you do?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: How do you do?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I have overcome my passion, and thought better.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Oh, very well—then 'tis all over.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: You impudent rascal, how dare you stand between me and my friend?— Begone, you scoundrel!—I thought you would see the absurdity of my supporting Greville.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Oh yes; it would have been quite out of character.

div3.stage: Music plays. Rostrum, singing—"See the conquering hero," &c. enters leading in EGERTON and ROSE SYDNEY.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Heyday! my ward here! why, girl—?
sp.stage: (goes up to her, and they converse in dumb shew.)

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Come here—come here—give me your hand, you dog—I suppose 'tis all settled.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: It is—the wedding's over.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I say—what will that old fool April say, I wonder?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: We shall hear.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I understand. Mr. Undermine, have you given our ward permission to marry?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: To be sure I have.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: If that be the case, my dear, you have mine.

sp.speaker: Eger.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: He thank me! what has he to do with it. Oh! I forgot he helped you to this delicious morsel.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: No, he did not; he helped himself—and what is more, persuaded a parson to say grace.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Egerton her husband! Did not I order you to marry her? Did not I bid—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: You did bid, sir; but honor bid more.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I give you joy, my girl. You have chosen a noble fellow.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Well, and I give her joy, for she has chosen a beggar.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: On that point I beg to be heard. You remember you gave me a key—here it is.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Well, sir?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: It belonged, ladies and gentlemen, to an escrutoire, with a secretary drawer. Pannells richly fineered—scrole pediment head—bracket feet—the whole finished in a workmanlike manner, and well worth the attention—

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: At the auctioneer again. Zounds! you are so fond of it, I dare say you would sell me.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Sir, I would knock you down with all the pleasure in life.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: But what of the key?—the key—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
The key certainly opened the drawer you
mentioned; and it as certainly opened a drawer you did not mention.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Be quiet. There I found a parcel of papers, and title deeds, which you must have put there entirely by mistake, my dear sir, because I perceived they belonged to Mr. Egerton.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Give them to me directly, directly—I say, sir, restore—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Every thing to its right owner. Certainly —I don't wish to keep your, or any man's property —so, Egerton, there are your papers again— and, Uncle, there is your key again.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Eger.
sp.p: What disinterested integrity!

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: What damned rascality!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh fie! no, no.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: What is it then?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Management.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Well, you have managed finely for yourself however—I discard you. Had you followed my instructions, you would have been exalted—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: To the pillory, I suppose.—No sir, tho' you don't scruple it to others, far be it from me to rob you of your natural inheritance.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I would have left you all I am worth.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: What then? you forget all you are worth belongs to other people. When you were gone, they would naturally ask me for their own, and how could I have the face to refuse them?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Give me your hand. You have acted your part nobly; and now 'tis my turn.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: All this I laugh at. Am I not possessed of the Greville estate? Who has any thing to say on that subject!

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I believe I shall trouble you with a word or two.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I see Greville is about to depart, and I must beg you will all follow his example.

div3.stage: Enter Mr. and Mrs. GREVILLE, SALLY following with a small bundle, and weeping.

sp.speaker: Eger.
sp.p: My best friends, allow me to present to you a sister. By this gentleman's kindness, Maria, happiness again dawns upon us.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: And I will make it blaze with meridian splendour.

sp.speaker: Grev.
sp.p: Let us then leave this man to the full enjoyment of such reflections as his conscience may administer.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I beg your pardon a moment. Umph! Mr. Undermine, I hear doubts have arisen respecting the authenticity of the late Mr. Greville's signature.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Indeed!—Sir, to shew my fairness, I'll leave this point to your decision.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: 'Tis genuine, it must be confessed.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Must it so?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Any objection to my reading it?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Perhaps it may tire you?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: By no means. I think it remarkably entertaining.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I, Robert Greville, do declare this my last will.— To my only son, Charles Greville, I give and bequeath my forgiveness and my blessing, together with all my estates real and personal.— Umph! that is very entertaining.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Very—but I prefer the remainder—"Provided my said son"—go on—go on.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: 'Pshaw!—"Provided my said son has not "contracted"—why don't you go on?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I don't see any thing like it.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: You don't—ha, ha! Give me leave to direct your attention.
sp.stage: (looks at the will, drops his hat and cane, and groans deeply.)

sp.speaker: Grev.
sp.p: What does this mean!

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Mean!—That my young master, my friend, my dear Charles, is happy—that my old master is in heaven, and that I am in heaven; two wills were made; by the last, which he endeavoured to suppress, you are sole heir, without reservation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Grev.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Grev.
sp.p: How shall I express my gratitude for this discovery?—for giving happiness to my Maria?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: And to me too. Oh, you are a nice old man.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: He must have dealt with—

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Old Nick. You are right—I did—and here he comes.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Ah, Nicholas—Nicholas!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Ah, master—master!

sp.speaker: Und
sp.p: A dreadful affair this!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Very shocking indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Eh—zounds! I have given him a draft for a thousand pounds. (coaxingly.) Nicholas— Come here, Nicholas. I am not angry. My consolation is, what's done, can't be undone. I gave you a draft—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: You did, sir. And my consolation is, what's done, can't be undone.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Indeed! But it will be of no use. I have no cash at my banker's.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Dear sir, what credit you have! They paid it without a word.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: You have not been—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Yes, sir—I just contrived to hobble there.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: You infernal! (gulping down his passion.) Old friends should not quarrel, Nicholas; suppose we go home, and talk it over agreeably. I'll propose something reasonable.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: It must be very reasonable.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: It shall. Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: What, bowing! You forget, sir, your own lessons.—Be erect, and I'll tell you how you may be so;—become an honest man, and on my life, that will make you hold up your head more gallantly than the first dancing master in Europe can;—depend on't, sir. Roguery is the worst trade a man can follow; for (to the credit of human nature) I sincerely believe, that where one fortune is raised by pursuing the devious mazes of chicanery, a hundred are acquired by walking in the simple path of industrious integrity.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: You had better stick to management!

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Management!—Oh, I have had enough of that.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Now, being all as happy as heart can wish, come along with me, Sally. Good bye to you—

sp.speaker: Grev.
sp.p: Where are you going, April?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p:
To the kitchen. I have no notion of your houses, not I, where all the joy is confined to
the drawing-room. Let there be degrees in every thing but happiness; and 'fore George, if any servant in this house be sober enough to wait on you at supper, I'll discharge him to-morrow morning. —Poor fellows! must not make them ill tho' Never mind—Come along Sally.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Oh, you are a nice old man!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: If I must have thanks, gentlemen, let me receive them here!— (kissing the ladies' hands.) Happy fellows! you are to be envied.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Grev.
sp.p: So are you. We have received happiness, you have given it.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Your fortunes, sir, will be our peculiar care.

sp.speaker: Ros
sp.p: Thank you, dear ladies; but, with your permission, I'll stick to my trade.
sp.l: And oh! could all my pray'rs but gain this lot,
To raise my pulpit nightly on this spot;
Then your poor Auctioneer would prize his station,
While you vouchsafed one nod of approbation.

lg.l: SECRETS worth knowing—Shall I tell you one?
Don't frown, or our poor Bard will be undone.
Change to a grin his present woeful phiz,
Last year he cur'd your Heart Ache, now cure his.
But leaving him, as we're left here alone,
Suppose I tell a secret of my own.
Know then, I think—tho' women will be craving.
Your men-folks at the best are scarce worth having.
No more entire—they go about by halves,
Like legs consumptive, that have lost their calves;
What with their crops, slouched gait, and short surtouts,
Half heads, half tails, half manners, and half boots.
A wife, or an old maid! Aye, that's the question;
Both bitter pills, and bad for our digestion;
The prim old maid detests all amorous hussies,
Her nursery's confin'd to pups and pussies;
Pug's her gallant, and her dear fondled baby,
Master Grimalkin, or grey-ey'd miss Tabby.
"Man, what an animal! to love to hug,
"Puppies they are; but not like my sweet pug,
"Prating as parrots, obstinate as donkies;
"We'd better all lead apes than follow monkies."
The wife poor thing, at first so blithe and chubby,
Scarce knows again her lover in her hubby;
No more—"my charming dear! my sweetest life,"
'Tis—"stir that fire, give me some coffee, wife."
"There —now you've burnt my fingers;—what a ninny
"My dog's more nouse than you, I'll bet a guinea!"
He flies about to swallow port by dozens;
She stays at home, to mope with aunts and cousins.
Some wives there are, perhaps as well intentioned,
More spirited than such as I have mentioned;
Flirt at the opera, gamble at quadrille,
Run down a character, run up a bill;
Should spouse not be at dinner to say grace,
Can find a substitute to fill his place;
Invade man's province, bluster and look big,
Nor wear the breeches only, but the wig.
Enchanting taste! each day we change our hue,
White, auburn, grizzle, tye-wig, scratch or queue.
The red-hair'd lass, to hide her golden nob,
Tucks up her tresses in a nut-brown bob.
And full blown dames, thro' time a little flaxen,
Conceal that outrage by a coal-black caxen,
Nay, prosing belies, however bald the pate,
Can by this means insure a tête-a-tête.
To shew I prize the mode, and would not mock it,
I carry all my graces in my pocket,
These are the native charms with which I shine, (takes out a wig.))
A stampt receipt will prove that they are mine. (puts on the wig.)
How do I look? Methinks 'tis grand to move (walks about with wig on.)
Beneath the covert of this curly grove.
It shields one too; for, should some wag, in scoff,
Assault my scratch, he can but scratch it off.
Shall I, in future, then, this helmet wear?
Decree, and I'll obey you to a Hair.

div1.head: NEW PUBLICATIONS PRINTED FOR T. N. LONGMAN, No. 39, Paternoster-Row.
div1.p: 1. WALSINGHAM; or, the PUPIL of NATURE; a Domestic Story, interspersed with Poetry. By MARY ROBINSON, Author of Angelina, Poems, &c. &c. In Four large Volumes, 12mo. Price 16s. sewed.
2. FAMILY SECRETS, Literary and Domestic. By Mr. PRATT.
div1.quote: Concerning those things wherein men's lives and persons are most conversant.
div1.p: In five large volumes, 12mo. Price 1l. 5s. Boards.
div1.quote: Mr. Pratt has introduced to a numerous set of readers a novel that has the merit of being at once tender, pathetic, and full of love; and, which may be a more uncommon circumstance, of love mixed with the greatest discretion.
In the volumes before us, there are several beautiful and affecting strokes of nature.
div1.p: 3. A GOSSIP's STORY and LEGENDARY TALE. By Mrs. WEST, Author of Advantages of Education, &c. In two Volumes 12mo. Price 7s. in Boards.
div1.quote: We can recommend this story as uniting to a great degree of interest the rarer qualities of good sense, and an accurate knowledge of mankind. The grammatical errors and vulgarisms which disgrace many even of our most celebrated novels, have here no place; and several of the shorter poetical pieces interspersed through the work, have very considerable merit. Amusement is combined with utility, and fiction is inlisted in the cause of virtue and practical philosophy.
div1.p: 4. CLARA DUPLESSIS and CLAIRANT: The HISTORY of a FAMILY of FRENCH EMIGRANTS. Translated from the German. In Three Volumes, 12mo. Price 10s. 6d. Boards.
This pathetic novel, or relation of facts, has been deservedly successful in its, native country, and at Paris.—
The characters are drawn with a truth of nature which is truly admirable.

5. ANECDOTES of TWO WELL KNOWN FAMILIES. Written by a Descendant, and dedicated to the first Female Pen in England. Prepared for the Press, by Mrs. PARSONS. In Two Vols. 12mo. Price 10s. 6d. in Boards.
6. AN OLD FRIEND WITH A NEW FACE; a Novel. By Mrs. PARSONS. In Three Volumes. Price 10s. 6d. Boards.

7. BIOGRAPHICAL, LITERARY, and POLITICAL ANECDOTES, of-several of the most EMINENT PERSONS of the PRESENT AGE; particularly the Dukes of Grafton, Leeds, Dorset, and Rutland; Lords Townshend, Orford, Marchmont, Mansfield, Camden, Temple, Nugent, and Sackville; Bishops of Hereford and Ossory; Right Hon. George Grenville, Charles Townshend; Sir James Caldwell, Sir Grey Cooper, Sir John Dalrymple, Serjeant Adair, Dr. Franklin, and many others. Never before printed; in Three Volumes. Price 18s.
The Monthly Critics, who have already reviewed this new work, speak of it in the following words:

The writers of the Monthly Revicw for last month say, "We cannot dismiss these volumes without observing, that they contain a considerable portion of political information. The work will, by its discerning readers, be characterized as highly interesting; and it will prove particularly so to those who still remember the times to which the anecdotes here recorded are referable. To the future historian also it will afford much assistance, by contributing, in many instances, towards the means of information, which, but for publications of this kind, might be utterly consigned to oblivion.

The writers of the Analytical Review for January last, say, "The work before us will be found particularly interesting to those who wish to obtain an idea of the management of state affairs in this country, during the whole of the present reign."

The writers of the Gentleman's Magazine for January last, say, "These volumes are written by the author of the Anecdotes of the late Earl of Chatham, and are not inferior to that work either in interest or intelligence. Those persons who are fond of reading the political anecdotes of their own times, particularly from the year 1760 to the year 1780, (an important period), which, the writer assures us, have not been printed, will receive fiom this work much pleasure and information."

The writers of the European Magazine, say, "The editor of these volumes is entitled to the thanks of the public, for preserving many facts which otherwise might have fallen into oblivion. The reader will find entertainment and information in them, and the future investigator of the acts of the present reign will meet with some valuable materials to exercise his sagacity upon, which are to be no where else found, and which will serve to guide him through the obscure paths of political finesse."
8. The ANECDOTES of LORD CHATHAM's LIFE. The Sixth Edition. In Three Volumes, 8vo. Price 18s. Boards.
div1.quote: The author has made a valuable Collection of Anecdotes, especially of the late and most conspicuous part of Lord Chatham's Life; and of other matters connected with it. He says he is not conscious of having advanced one falsehood: We give credit to his declaration, having found no cause to doubt it.
div1.p: A greater number of curious and interesting anecdotes, concerning public affairs, have not appeared since the days of Sir William Temple, than are to be found in this work.
We cannot dismiss this article without acknowledging, that it throws a great and new light upon the occurences and events of more than half a century of our history.

9. A RESIDENCE in FRANCE, during the Years 1792, 3, 4, & 5; described in a Series of Letters from an ENGLISH LADY, with general and incidental Remarks on the French Character and Manners. Prepared for the Press by JOHN GIFFORD Esq. In Two Volumes, 8vo. Price 14s. Boards. The Third Edition.
div1.quote: It is only justice to say, that the style is as polished as the matter is interesting and important: nor have we any doubt that the book will remain a permanent monument of the taste and talents of the writer.
div1.p: 10. GLEANINGS THROUGH WALES, HOLLAND, and WESTPHALIA; with Views of Peace and War at Home and Abroad. To which is added, HUMANITY; or, The Rights of Nature: A Poem. Revised and corrected. By Mr. PRATT. In Three Volumes, 8vo. Price One Guinea in Boards. Third Edition.
div1.quote: We have found so many lively and pleasant exhibitions of manners, so many amusing and interesting anecdotes, and so many observations and reflections, gay and grave, sportive and sentimental, (all expressed in a gay and familiar style,) better suited to the purpose than sentences laboured with artificial exactness, that we cannot but recommend it to our readers as a highly amusing and interesting performance.
div1.p: 11. An HISTORY, or ANECDOTES of the REVOLUTION in RUSSIA, in the Year 1762. Translated from the French of M. DERULHIERE. With an elegant Head of the late EMPRESS. Second Edition. Price 4s. sewed.

The grounds of M. De Rulhiere's information seem indisputable, and his readers appear to have every reason to be satisfied with his discernment, in unfolding the motives and circumstances that concurred in bringing about this striking event. He is no servile copier, but has drawn his characters, and described his scenes, with the hand of a master.
We shall only add, that we have seldom met with more interesting original anecdotes, than those that are contained in the little work which we have now reviewed.

p.hi: In the Press, and speedily will be published.
